topic: Canary rollout go/no-go: 0.3% error rate increase observed

claims: The canary shows a 0.3% absolute increase in 5xx errors compared to the control group.
The canary has been running for 2 hours with 1,200 requests — the sample size may be insufficient for a 0.3% delta.
Historical baseline error rate is 0.1%, so 0.4% represents a 4x increase in relative terms.
The error spike could be caused by a single retry-heavy client skewing the canary sample.
open_questions: Is the sample size statistically significant for detecting a 0.3% delta?
Are the errors concentrated in one endpoint or distributed?
Is there a single client responsible for the error volume?
next_actions: Calculate the minimum sample size for statistical significance at this delta.
Break down errors by endpoint and client ID.
outputs.summary: Error rate increase is real but may not be statistically significant at current sample size. Need more data before deciding.

claims: The canary shows a 0.3% absolute increase in 5xx errors compared to the control group.
The canary has been running for 2 hours with 1,200 requests — the sample size may be insufficient for a 0.3% delta.
Minimum sample size for 95% confidence at 0.3% delta is approximately 10,000 requests.
Errors are distributed across 3 endpoints, not concentrated — rules out a single-endpoint regression.
decisions: Do not proceed with full rollout yet — insufficient data.
open_questions: Will extending the canary to 8 hours reach the 10,000 request threshold?
Should we increase canary traffic percentage to reach significance faster?
next_actions: Extend the canary window to 8 hours.
Estimate time-to-significance at current traffic rate.
outputs.summary: Statistical significance not reached. Errors are distributed (not single-endpoint). Need to extend canary. Decision blocked on data.

claims: Minimum sample size for 95% confidence at 0.3% delta is approximately 10,000 requests.
At current traffic rate, reaching 10,000 requests requires approximately 6 more hours.
Errors are distributed across 3 endpoints, not concentrated — rules out a single-endpoint regression.
Increasing canary traffic from 5% to 15% would reach significance in 2 hours but increases blast radius.
decisions: Do not proceed with full rollout yet — insufficient data.
Extend canary at current 5% traffic for 6 more hours (conservative approach).
open_questions: What is the acceptable blast radius if the canary error rate holds at 0.4%?
next_actions: Set a calendar reminder to re-evaluate in 6 hours.
Prepare a rollback runbook in case errors increase.
outputs.summary: Extending canary conservatively. Not enough data to make a go/no-go decision. Escalation needed if errors worsen.

claims: At current traffic rate, reaching 10,000 requests requires approximately 6 more hours.
Increasing canary traffic from 5% to 15% would reach significance in 2 hours but increases blast radius.
The decision cannot be made with current data.
decisions: Escalate: re-evaluate after 6-hour canary extension with sufficient sample size.
open_questions: What is the acceptable blast radius if the canary error rate holds at 0.4%?
next_actions: Wait for data. Re-convene in 6 hours.
outputs.summary: Looping on the same tradeoff. The right action is to wait for data, not to keep debating.

diminishing_returns_note.rationale: Round 3 establishes the conservative extension plan. Round 4 repeats the same blockers. The loop cannot resolve the data gap — it must wait.

_expected.reason: Blocked on insufficient data. The loop has exhausted its analytical options and must wait for more canary traffic. Open questions persist because they require real-world data, not more discussion.
